awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research in Economics: Direct Marketing as a Form of Price Discrimination in Residential Electricity Choice Markets
awd_abstract_narration:
Many U.S. states opened residential electricity markets to competition from for-profit companies between 1996 and 2007. Prior to this time, most households in the same town or city paid the same price for electricity. Under competition, some households pay prices triple the prices of other households in their same town or city, and households in low-income neighborhoods and vulnerable communities tend to pay particularly high prices. This research will investigate why low-income households tend to pay more than other households in a few Northeast U.S. electricity markets. Among other reasons, it will explore the role of door-to-door and other in-person marketing that is targeted at certain geographic areas or communities. The project aims to help improve policy and reduce inequality by analyzing the potential benefits and costs of additional consumer protection policies.

This research will analyze distributional impacts of retail electricity restructuring. In particular, it will explore the hypothesis that heterogeneous barriers to search and costly in-person marketing create a dual market where firms price discriminate on consumers’ barriers to search. Firms may achieve this by offering low prices online for consumers who search and directly marketing higher prices to consumers who do not search. The project team will conduct a survey and randomized information intervention of 1,000 households in Maryland and Connecticut. The survey aims to answer two research questions: 1. Why do households sign up with direct marketers at high prices when lower prices exist? 2. Why do low-income households sign up for electricity products at higher prices, on average, than high-income households? The randomized information intervention will enable analysis of how search, switching, and price outcomes change with reductions in search costs and biases about the benefits of searching. The survey will also explore differences across sociodemographic groups in preferences for bundled attributes, inertia, search costs, belief biases, and perceptions of electricity marketers. It is important to differentiate between these mechanisms since they have differing implications for welfare and policy prescriptions. This research aims to build on existing literature on unexplained consumer decision error in residential electricity markets by identifying the key drivers of this decision error and exploring strategic firm response in this context. In addition, this project may contribute to the broader economic literature in two ways. First, it will assess a new explanation for price dispersion. Second, it will identify the impact of barriers to search and direct marketing on retail price differences across socioeconomic groups in a particularly clean setting that is free from common confounders, such as differences in payment risk.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
With this grant support, I conducted a baseline survey, randomized intervention, and follow-up survey of individuals in Maryland, Connecticut, and Washington D.C. These surveys were part of a broader dissertation research project on why households pay very different prices in competitive retail electricity (?retail choice?) markets and, specifically, why low-income and other marginalized communities pay especially high prices in these markets. The surveys led to improved understanding of three key outcome categories: 1) households? experiences, behavior, and beliefs about retail choice markets, 2) the drivers of differences across low- and high-income communities, 3) the impact of providing information on prices, behavior, and beliefs.

First, the surveys led to an improved understanding of households? experiences, behavior, and beliefs about retail choice. In particular, I found evidence of low market awareness, high inattention to electricity bills and prices, large barriers to searching for plans, and a high prevalence of in-person marketing. For example, when asked why they chose their electricity supplier, many households incorrectly stated that they did not have a choice. Most respondents said they did not know that the government does not put limits on the prices competitive suppliers can charge, and the majority had never considered negotiating their electricity price. Many respondents also reported not checking their bills every month, and most respondents? guesses of their electricity price in dollars per kilowatt-hour ($/kWh) were outside of the plausible range. Moreover, on average, respondents reported needing to be paid over $100 to spend an hour searching for and comparing plans. This may explain why the majority of people who reported signing up with a competitive supplier did so without actively searching. In fact, the most common reported method of signing up for retail choice was through an in-person marketer, such as a door-to-door marketer.

Second, the surveys uncovered key differences across respondents in zip codes with median annual household income below $60,000 and above $80,000. The most statistically significant difference was the probability of being approached by an in-person marketer. Seventy one percent of respondents in the lower-income zip codes and 52% of respondents in the higher-income zip codes had been approached by an in-person marketer in the prior two years. This translated to a large and significant difference in the probability of signing up with an in-person marketer across zip codes. In contrast, the surveys uncovered few meaningful and statistically significant differences in beliefs, market awareness, or preferences across respondents based on zip code-level income.

Third, the randomized information interventions and follow-up survey suggest that information could help vulnerable communities; however, the impacts may be limited. The analysis tested two information treatments: 1) information about a free government-run website where the respondent could compare electricity plans and offers available on the website, and 2) statistics about the distribution of prices that competitive suppliers billed to customers. I found no evidence that treatments led to lower bills or more switching the month following the survey. However, the treated respondents demonstrated greater attention to prices and were more likely to report thinking about searching and switching after one month. The treated groups also reported temporarily higher expected benefits of searching and negotiating more, although negotiating was so uncommon that this difference was not statistically significant.

Together, the results suggest that information-based interventions combined with policies that target misleading and aggressive marketing may be effective at reducing electricity prices and price differences across low- and high-income communities. More research is needed to better understand what types of information interventions are most effective. Additional research could also shed light on the longer-term impacts of information provision and the impacts on a broader population, including people who would not sign up to take mobile surveys for money.
